Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation and Muscle Weakness in Astronauts

Exploring solutions for muscle atrophy in long-duration space missions.

Introduction

The progression of human space exploration towards long-duration interplanetary missions necessitates a comprehensive understanding of the physiological challenges imposed by the microgravity environment [1]. Among the most significant health concerns is the rapid degradation of skeletal muscle mass and function, a condition termed muscle atrophy, which can substantially impair crew performance during missions and pose significant risks to crew health upon re-exposure to a gravitational field [2].

This website provides a comprehensive review of the etiology of this condition, the affected demographic, the current therapeutic countermeasures, and their inherent limitations. It further proposes electrode-based muscle stimulation as a viable and technologically efficient intervention to mitigate this critical health risk.
